posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

I beat GTA III twice this week, and I think that its strength is that it realizes it's mostly a driving game with car theft and light combat being a little deviation to spice up the gameplay. When you approach the game primarily as a driving game, you're going to get better mission design, because it focuses on what the game does well: the driving. Still love VC and SA. Love them for what they are, but I also feel that III set out to do what it intended better than those two games did.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So I've been trying to understand, how exactly is Mega Drive viewed in Japan? Anyone who can contribute on this topic?
I've been looking at the game sales to get a general idea. There doesn't seem to be much data on game sales available, but the 2 lists Ive found paint a pretty similar picture—and it's pretty interesting.
Ironically, the #1 game on MD supposedly was Puyo Puyo. And looks like Sonic was quite popular on it, ending the meme that "no one knows Sonic in Japan"—MD simply sold like shit, and Sonic with it.
That said, the top was clearly dominated by RPGs, with Shining and Phantasy Star, and even games like Langrisser 2. No wonder Sega later wanted to have more RPGs on the platform.
Mega CD sold relatively well in Japan, so a few games for it made it to the top, like, interestingly, Silpheed, an even a fucking Night Trap.
Anyway, it's pretty surprising to see a list like this. Then again, it's clear that action games were far more popular in the West than in Japan, and it clearly had more appeal there with stuff like Streets of Rage, Golden Axe, Comix Zone, all the platformers, Mortal Kombat, sports games, and so on.
(1/3)

>>9495735
>>9495731
A chart comparing the console sales also sheds some light on the subject. Basically, MD was more or less doing ok, competing with PCE until around 1991-92. But then, SFC released and quickly overtook both of them. Sega CD helped slightly, but then again, PCE also had the CD add-on and Turbo Duo, which did better.
All in all, I guess Sega's arcade titles didn't really mean that much in Japan. What people wanted was Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy, and they continued buying the console that gave it to them until mid 2000s. Also, Nintendo was still strong after the success of the Famicom, and basically the competition had no chance going toe to toe with them.

>>9495951
they used to say the SFC was for everyone who wasn't a gamer which explains why it was full of shovelware licensed games, Mahjong, and horse racing sims. Mega Drive fans were more shmup and fighting game people who tended to be different and more hardcore than the more casual JRPG audience and the scene was also heavily import-focused as Japanese MD owners had no choice but to import a lot of US Genesis games.

to an extent this was true of the US as well with the SNES being marketed as a kid/family-friendly console and lacking Sega's tough guy image.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9496158
Japan cared more about Square / Enix, and way less so about arcade action, so SFC dominated there. But in the West, they cared way more about action, sports and mascot platformers, so one of Nintendo's biggest advantages meant very little there.
Also note that almost all of the best-selling SFC games in Japan were exclusives (save for a few like Street Fighter 2 or Puyo Puyo). But in the West, again due to popularity of the sports and cartoon games, a lot of the biggest sellers were multiplats. Mortal Kombat, NFL / NBA Jam, Aladdin, Lion King etc. came out on both platforms. So again, the gap narrowed hard. Genesis getting a lot of Western developer titles also didn't help.
And yes, Sega's marketing and Ninty's kiddy image in the West could've hurt too, but it's hard to say how much.
Regardless, data may vary, but according to NPD, Genesis was often beating SNES (albeit not by much) until late '94. It took DKC for Nintendo to truly give an answer to Sega. (see https://www.sega-16.com/forum/showthread.php?26110-January-December-1994-NPD-sales-data! ).

OK. Here's one for North America, a comparison of top selling games for N64 vs PSX. Interesting chart, since it confirms the popular opinion that "N64 didn't have that many games, but the few ones that were big were truly huge". Simply put, it's a more complex game. You forget that your average normie wouldn't even understand rotating camera / the whole Mario moveset / complicated puzzles / etc. Have you seen women play video games? They often can't even figure out basic stuff like holding B to run.
Every lost dummy like that is a lost sale on the market. That's the big reason a lot of the modern games have been dumbed down so much, with hour long tutorials like "press up to go forward".
Whole genres have seen this fate, like e.g. death of RTS and switch to MOBA. Because of increased budgets, you need to sell at least a million or more units just to break even. You have to target more people, and reach out to non-gamers. Appealing to a bunch of hardcore nerds isn't feasible in these conditions.

>>9497734
GBA game world totals. Posting this one because I haven't yet and it's somewhat interesting.
Obviously, the top positions are Pokemon, SNES ports of Mario / Zelda / DKC, and NES Classics games. Still Mario Kart at #4, though I don't know if many played it via link cable—but I guess MK is always MK and will sell anywhere. At #8 you have Namco Museum, that series actually sold a fuckton back in the day; and after that at #9 Pac-Man collection. Kinda sad that today most of those ports / collections don't really hold much value (especially with their washed out colors).
Pretty good though that they are followed by Wario Land 4, Mario & Luigi: Superstar Saga, Kirby: Nightmare in Dream Land, proving that GBA wasn't just for ports and Pokemon.
Sadly though, you have Finding Nemo immediately after those. You also have such gems on the list as The Incredibles (#31), Frogger's Adventures: Temple of the Frog (#33) (I still don't know how the fuck that series managed to make such a resurgence in late '90s–early '00s), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (#34), and Disney Princess (#35), which is perhaps what your average kid on the school bus played. I think the 2000s were the heyday of licensed shovelware, it prospered on PS2 too.
On the positive note, there's still a big number of good games on the list, like The Legend of Zelda: The Minish Cap, Golden Sun, FFTA, Metroid Fusion, and even the 2 WarioWare games.
Alas, some of the best games like the 3 Castlevanias, Advance Wars, Mega Man Zero 1-4, and many others are not on the list.
All in all, this reminds me that most people actually owned either Mario Advance games, Pokemon, or cartoon game shovelware for it.

I read up about how to go about fixing convergence though and it looks like there's three ways to go about it, depending on the gravity of the issue.
>Move the Horizontal alignment physical thingy inside the chassis.
>Move the Vertical alignment rings around the yoke itself.
>Stick more convergence strips inside the yoke, maybe even move magnets around.
In my case, the convergence is only really off on the borders of the image, so I only really need to play around with the "convergence strips", whatever that is. Will look into some home-made strips though, since I really doubt I'll be able to find these things on sale at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485672
>That's not how TVL works.
Stupid faggot, that's exactly how it works

TVL = Horizontal Resolution
SNES/Genesis after PAR adjustment = 292x224

Assuming no overscan you can display all detail with 292TVL and and anything more than that and it looks oversharpened.
But CRTs always have overscan so you can never get it perfect.

Example
Top
15 inch consumer CRT component

Bottom
500 line PVM 14 inch RGB

The lower TVL looks far far better
But even that isn't perfect since you have screen-door effect because of the dot pitch being bigger than the pixel pitch.
The only way to achieve perfection is near-neighbour scaling into 12000-20000 PPI displays which is still a long way off.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9488437
Oh hey good timing, you asked right as I was checking back on this thread
I had two wired Retrofighters Brawler64s that crapped out on me. Basically the analog stick started dropping inputs, so for example if you were running forward as Link in OoT he would stop and start - essentially unusable. Both had the exact same problem.
Unfortunately they both had fallen just outside the warranty window, and their support didn't even reply when I sent them like a "Hey, anything I can try to do to fix these?"
About a year later someone on twitter was asking about them, and I outlined that whole chain of events to them and said that I don't recommend them at all. From that tweet, their PR/customer support team reached out to me and ultimately actually shipped me two of the newer wireless versions by way of apology. And the wireless one has held up a lot better than the originals. At least, so far.
So maybe the takeaway is, they used to be utter crap, and now are (hopefully) a lot better. The analog stick on all of these these is just kind of weird though.

In the interim I used the wired Retro-Bit Tribute64 (which is modeled after the famous Hori N64 controller) and I actually liked this a lot better than any of the Brawler64s. The only problem with these is that the connector has an absolute death grip on the controller port, which is why I switched back to the wireless Brawler64 for right now - since I didn't want to be unplugging and replugging that controller all the time, and wireless controllers just keep things a bit more tidy. You know how it is.

There is an N64 controller purist on this board who will tell you that the analog stick sensitivity and deadzones of any of these 3rd party controllers is crap compared to the original - he's got charts and whatnot to back it up. He's probably right, but it's never really bothered me and or caused any real problems.

Of these I'd recommend the Tribute64 first.

>>9490051
>>9491313
Safest bet would be to open the thing and check all capacitors with an ESR calculator. Replace the bad ones with new capacitors of the same specifications and pray that it works.
When it comes to these old machines, capacitors are almost always the suspect number one because they tend to fail earlier and when they do fail (and they will), they bulge up and start leaking on the main board, so you want to take care of that as soon as humanly possible.
If you aren't one for soldering, you could ask someone to do it, but it's questionable whether professionals will work on CRTs nowadays. Definitely a good skill to have though or, in my case, know someone who does that kind of thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9492425
that's pretty tough to answer
generally with gen 7 imo you want to be on a modern TV because all of gen 7 supported 480p (and beyond), and your CRT will likely only support 480i
So while gen 7 consoles can output a 480i signal that works on consumer CRTs, the software was pretty much all designed for 480p (or 720p, in the case of most PS3 games afaik). So right out of the gate on a PS3, you're taking a huge quality loss when using a CRT just because of the signals it can handle.

Pretty much all of the "Wow, this looks way better than my old CRT!" talk comes from back in the day when people were viewing a 480i signal on their CRT and then switched to a 480p signal on their flatscreen during gen 7. And I don't really think there are any games where you'd be like, "Now THIS. THIS game was MADE for a CRT!!", that's all up to personal taste.

I dont know why you dont get this, but 540p is progressive 1080i
If a TV supports 1080i natively it supports 540p.
Pretty much nothing uses 540p, but it is still lagless and you can input it with a PC via VGA or even component with a transcoder.
https://www.avsforum.com/threads/do-crts-have-a-native-resolution.556870/
Majority of HDCRTS sale 720p to 1080i
Another example of a Sony:
https://shmups.system11.org/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=68605
Some expensive HDCRTs do support 480p and 720p because they are cummonly used, but it requires some multiscanning capabilities in the TV and non multiscan crts scale 720p and 480p.

Anon, please don't do this. As other people have stated, you can find a great TV set for free or around 50 dollars or less price range, if you actually take the time to look. CRT’s can fail and need costly repairs and you don’t want to be stuck with that bill if you can avoid it. Let alone when you are talking about dropping a 1,000 dollars or so on a 20 year old TV set. >>9495996
>Why the fuck does literally no one make a modern CRT?
It's because it's just too expensive. No one manufactures CRT TV anymore. The production cost was so low (insanely low) in the late 2000's for that reason alone. You could pick a mid to semi high grade CRT for 100 - 300 bucks brand new.
> I'm kind of treating these as a real TV purchase, not just for retro games like I said.
>I just want to also be able watch movies and TV shows on it in acceptable quality.
Be prepared to make some compromises you might not be thinking about. I have a Sylvania 6420FF (20 inches) I use for my bedroom TV and I don't think most modern consumers would care for that. If you want to use normal TV that way (over the air TV), you are going to need a converter box unless you have cable. I think CRT TV’s have their uses for sure (retro), but you need to use them in the best way possible. Think of it as a hobby TV, not your main one. They look great using old video game systems and DVD’s, but if you are approaching the HD stuff, it’s really not the best use for it. You'll be looking at 16:9 bars.

sync would probably work. if the voltages lined up and you could get a display to read a composite signal as rgb then since the r, g, and b values would always be the same as each other, the resulting image wouldn't have any color. it would essentially just be brightness information. the color information would be interpreted as brightness and appear as dot crawl but otherwise be lost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9501654
>8 ms
You're probably referring to pixel response time, which has more to do with motion clarity (or rather a lack thereof, i.e. smearing) than input lag.
Generally PC monitors from that era will be OK, no input lag on those. I'm still daily driving a 2005 or so Samsung as my secondary display. Has some image retention issues, but it doesn't bother me with the way I use it.
That thing in your previous pic is an old LCD TV, those usually have very slow and sloppy image processing, causing horrendous input lag reaching over 100ms. If the set has a game mode, that will reduce the latency significantly, but it'll still be noticeable if you're used to modern displays or CRTs. Early LCD technology really was a dark age and I'm glad it's gone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9501665
>That thing in your previous pic is an old LCD TV, those usually have very slow and sloppy image processing, causing horrendous input lag reaching over 100ms.
According to the manual, it has 8 ms. I'm not sure what a CRT TV's typical expected response time is, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9501685
That's what I was talking about, it's just pixel response time, i.e. how fast the panel changes colors when fed some voltage. Older LCDs had higher response time (like yours), I think now most have about 2ms. OLED is nearly instantaneous at this, LCDs don't stand a chance.
However, that tells you nothing about how long it actually takes the signal to run from the input, through all the processing and to finally be displayed on screen. This is input lag and it will fuck you up on those old LCDs. Especially if you're using analog inputs and interlaced signal (240p too, because it's most often misinterpreted as 480i and needlessly deinterlaced, introducing additional lag on top of ugly artifacts).
Manufacturers have only started to mention it once it got fairly low in the recent years. I remember playing some 360 on my budget 32" LG, which had little to no processing (and that meant low input lag) and then hooking it up to my parents' Samsung (that had a much better picture, even in game mode) and being amazed at how sluggish everything was because of the latency.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9496679
Okay so the way the powerups work is that each colour is a different type of attack. To upgrade them you need to collect the same colour repeatedly without collecting the other colours, otherwise you go back to the lv1 version of the collected weapon. Try it, it will make a huge difference. Melee enemies that get close because itll either oneshot them or knock them back giving you room for a charge shot. They have very basic patterns to play around once you know how they work. Boss of stage 1 is a bit of a pain if you dont know the patterns and some require you get into position before the attack comes out. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9498287
Change your mindset on single player games and youll appreciate them more. Pattern recognition is a form of puzzle solving, where the player is rewarded for how quickly they can recognize and adapt to a challenge with an equal amount of skill execution thrown on top. The appeal of a single player action game is that once you've passed a skill check you move onto the next one in increasing levels of difficulty and complexity. Pvp and multiplayer in general is great for creating dynamic and evolving scenarios but it also doesnt give the player and clear linear progression of their skills or promise any variety to foster it. Theres a reason at uni I mostly made couch multiplayer games. It was a cheap shorthand to getting emergent play out of a few design elements. Put a character controller in a room with a ball they have to roll into a basket? Boring. Put two character controllers in a room with baskets for each of them? Watch the strategies emerge, add a few rock paper scissors elements and boom. good grades. As a player you feel more intelligent but as a designer you come to appreciate how brilliant a well designed single player game is. Anyway go play Sin And Punishment (the wii version) right now and give yourself 40 lashes when youre done. Also drop the high iq stuff its obnoxious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9497897
Considering I personally have experienced this trying to get into shmups myself yeah i'd say its a barrier for newcomers at the least. It was latter half of thunderforce iv. I prefer games give me a decent level of power by default but give me more power through skilled play which requires that i maintain that skill to keep the power from decaying in some way. I see a lot of shmups where the skill needed actually declines to more powerful you become. The scrolling sections become pushovers and the only threats being anything that can live to get a shot off and the bosses that can tank the damage. Its easy to develop bad habits when you spend most of a stage not seeing a single attack pattern. When a threat comes around that does challenge your damage output losing that output is a death sentence when you have so little familiarity with the stage. I think its more a case of power being to static 100-0 than a smooth gradient that causes the issue. As someone not too familiar with shmups i don't know how many buck that trend though or if Id see past it with more practice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember thinking the concept for these was really cool; like >>9501486 says, having the screen overlaying a 3D backdrop is a nice step up from a 2D vpet thing on a blank or barely visible background, and it’s a shame that concept wasn’t explored more before tech and the market seemed to move on to other gimmicks. According to a youtube reviewer who covers late 90s/early 2000s electronics, there were several neat easter eggs built into their design—not only were there the obligatory cashgrab interconnectivity gimmicks where you could connect devices to have one girl visit another’s house or go into a car/mall/whatever, but even just with one the little light in the upstairs window turns on a few seconds after she ascends the stairs to go to bed. The speakers were impressive too; they supported voice acting (by Tara Strong apparently) while other vpets were still limited to high-pitched beeps.
…When these were advertised, my horny teenage brain once dreamt that a line of these came out with different devices which catered to different fetishes. Part of me still thinks that there’s a market to be had for an adult version of these where you take care of your own virtual bored housewife or whatever.
I know these are a loose definition of /vr/ which is sure to incite arguments among “letter of the law” vs “spirit of the law” anons, even though it’s retro from within the right era and they’re just as much games as Game&Watch devices were; but I want to hear about other v-pet devices from this era, especially if they were able to connect with more traditional gaming devices. An anon on /toy/ vaguely described being able to connect modern day digivices to the original PS and Wonderswan games, but apparently several adapters are necessary to accomplish that.

>>9502898
I don't agree with the magnitude of this opinon, but I do agree with the intent. If the game isn't fun to 100% then don't do it. Enjoy it for what it is or was, rather than ruining your taste for it with overexposure.

As for dicking you over, I don't know that Rare was that bad. They cut their teeth in computing, and in my experience computer games are typically much crueler about secrets or about execution skill. Part of it I think is the hardware and the audience; Scrolling was a challenge on computers for years and years (while NES/etc. had dedicated hardware for it) and adults were more likely to own computers (in the US at least; Europe was more slanted toward all ages of course). At least for US output, however, that meant that you were more likely to get slower, thought-provoking games, rather than faster, dexterity-challenging games. Given a lack of space, however, you'd want to make the agme particularly cruel in its mental demands, since action-oriented play wasn't as feasible. So you end up with Wizardry rather than Makaimura, as two arbitrary examples.

I feel Rares catalogue of games had a habit of arbitrarily locking me out of the ending until I did some unrelated busywork. Like if we are being real; Why does beating the OG DK Arcade open K.Rools locked door in Hideout helm? Why does the chieftain cocksucker in JFG not just lend me his ship so I can take out Mizar and then maybe I can come back later to get all of his Tribals? Is it REALLY more urgent than saving the earth?

By contrast; Nintendos own games would usually give me context WHY I need some shit or not dick me around. In Mario 64, you only need 70 stars out of 120 to get to the final boss. Ocarina of Time didn't lock you out of Ganons fortress because you hadn't found all Skultulas. Star Fox 64 didn't force me to play a one-hit run of the first level of Star Fox 1 to get to the final battle with Andross, etc.

I still enjoyed their games, but even as a kid I thought Rares way of extending shelf life was just making their solutions completely random and unintuitive, unsolvable without a guide, or just making the requirement harder than it needed to be.

>>9500581
Ausfag here; we have some 'barcade' style arcades of varying quality. Some have real vintage machines in good condition along with overpriced beer. I don't mind those places, they're usually run by old dudes who know how to maintain and service the machines and really care about having them in good condition etc. The best ones are pretty active in holding community events like trivia nights or fighting game tournaments to keep people coming back and keep the novelty alive.
There's also a number of Timezone centers which is an old franchise from back in the 90s. It's mostly just ticket redemption machines, 'Raw Thrills' licensed shooters and some weird stuff like Angry Birds giant machines. They do have a lot of the rhythm games from Japan though. It's aimed at little kids and normies, so it's fine for what it is, but I never see much I want to play myself. I like seeing it have a resurgence though, since it's still a family owned company IIRC.

>>9500905
on how to use what? the original pcb?
you would just need an arcade power supply ($15-40)
a way to process RGB signal off the jamma edge
i just use a supergun and scart cable into retrotink rgb2comp>@2xpro works with most monitors

or if you want to be a cheap bastard the hyperkin genesis hdmi adapter will fit any supergun using genesis2 output ports
i have a small cabinet that uses one of those adapters permanently, the latency is still good enough to 1CC metalslug


as for generic "guides" you MUST always consult your original owners manual as sometimes the pinout (even though its jamma standard usually) will sometimes be mismatched


examples: soul edge (namco board) has a separate kick harness\board edge, tekken 2 does as well, etc

just take your time and read carefully
i use my mvs-1b as the control group
if the pinouts match closely enough to that its prob fine for supergun use


avoid the pandora pcb theyre usually garbage
60 in 1 \ 19 in 1 is fine, but i suggest using a 4way stick or you will be shitting it up

posts.com:
Silent hill 1: never played it

Silent hill 2: Goated, however, the horror was okay at best. I found myself laughing at the monsters most of the time. The puzzles were absolutely god-tier. There was a particular puzzle that managed to turn a group of 7 people into a frenzy on deciding what was the best answer for it. Highly recommend this game and the best in the series for me. The puzzle I am talking about is the coin puzzle. Also shout out Stanley Coleman, reading his logs in the hospital was epic.

Silent hill 3: Honestly one of the weirdest games I have played, I found myself questioning the game more than anything. The horror aspect was just not there for me honestly. Puzzles are dank as always.

Silent hill homecoming: hilarious yet fun game, I believe this game mixed with silent hill 2 would have been a masterpiece. Would be hard to pull off though.

silent hill downpour: did not finish it, forgettable game.

I do see that people are putting silent hill 2 & 3 over RE 4 and I just do not agree. Besides puzzles, it just does not compare. You could even argue atmosphere but it's not a strong case enough for me.

You could say I have a bias since I broke my horror game hymen with RE4 then played dead space after that. I would even put dead Space 1&2 over the silent hill games. That is just me.

This is not discounting silent hill games since I would play silent hill 2 in a heartbeat. Other than that, it's not the goat for me.

My first couple horror games were: RE4, dead space 1&2, Condemed 2: Bloodshot

posts.com: it seems a faux pas to say, but i think RE4 really is the best horror game. it has a lot of action and 80s tier one-liners, but it's easy to forget about some of the legitimately creepy moments. as a kid, i always ran through the village at night when you first get ashley because of how scary it was; being in this pitch black, rainy farmland with a bunch of demented spaniards lurking in the dark is pretty unsettling. that's to say nothing of the first time you see regenerators, or even stranger shit like the bag in the dumpster that convulses. the way the game uses music to build atmosphere is fantastic too -- e.g., the merchant theme which is calm and protective but always serves as a warning of something sinister to come. the game's ability to create a sense of claustrophobia and dread is frankly amazing.

posts.com: I've been getting into this genre the past few months and one aspect of this genre that really surprised me was the realization of just how small it really was. There's a million RE games, a handful of SH games that actually matter, and then a lot of one off shit that either never caught on or was based on an some IP at the time. RE has definitely cemented itself as a pop culture icon, so why did the actual survival horror genre die so quickly exactly? By seventh gen it was all but dead, with only a mild resurgence in recent years. Perhaps it's part of an appeal to the genre but so many other games in this genre generally feel more along the lines of "passion projects" with a number of apparent flaws that would turn off average consumers, only RE and SH really feel like true "big budget" experiences. I was only born in 98 but to anyone that grew up with it just how long did RE stay relevant? It feels like RE2 was definitely still fresh in the minds of people but by RE3 it seems like there was a decline in interest overall.

>>9487436
This is a great question, and I'll try to answer it from my own point of view. Personally, I feel that the only games that have ever tried to imitate Resident Evil are its own series, and Dino Crisis 1. This is even debatable, as truthfully the only REAL survival horror games, as in games that both combine survival AND horror, without going down the more action heavy route, are RE1, REmake, and Dino Crisis.

Back to the subject though, you'll notice all of REs knock-offs barely ever tried to imitate its style. Even Silent Hill, its greatest rip-off, is absolutely nothing like Resident Evil. It has virtually no item management, and ammo is not scarce at all. Most of the games just try to rip off its camera angle and let you shoot monsters. But how many tried to copy the Mansion, or added in interesting, well-thought backtracking? How many are actually scarce on ammunition, or force you to really strategize how you go through each room? It just doesn't exist. I'm not sure if Resident Evil was just that good, or the developers were just flat out lazy and all of the clones were cash grabs. But they aren't very good in comparison, and they all lack polish.

the *actual*, real thing that separates a "survival horror" game from something else is the true permanence of consequence, aka putting the onus of survival onto the player regardless of how easy or hard it is to achieve in actuality

RE1 is a survival horror game because it has truly finite resources and if you choose to shoot them onto a wall the game wont take pity on you and divine more resources from some enemys asshole, unlike RE4, dead space or the evil within

Call of Cthulhu DCOTE has light elements of survival horror but it doesnt commit into the design in its linear gauntlet that doesnt leave much space for consistent systems or long term consequences to ever really unlock the meaning of the label

RE4 is an action game and any type of mild (perceived) resource scarcity in that game only exists to incentivize actually interacting with the full action mechanics of the game (conserving resources by hitting weakspots and using the melee to either hit entire crowds or immediately damage one enemy as much as possible, using the knife, using the environmental tools) instead of just unloading into the crowd which would completely break the encounter design

>>9488479
I think SH3's strengths get overshadowed i general. It's a weird game in the series, it acts as a continuation of SH1's plot while telling a more personal narrative about Heather like SH2, making it feel "redundant" in ways. SH3 both tries to tell a deeper narrative happening around the protagonist and those around her but also have her experience her own personal journey, it's a very ambitious narrative that, overall, I would say works out well but doesn't feel quite as cohesive as the prior two entries. Generally I think people see SH3 as having "less meaning" in what the game, and this is true in a few regards but still pretty inaccurate to the overall. Honestly I think the symbolism and themes go over people's heads because they're so heavily based in the feminine experience. If you're a guy I feel like it's likely you just kind of don't think about things like the game's various menstrual imagery, though some things like the hole leading to the final boss are hard to miss.

I always have a hard time deciding between SH1 and SH3 as my personal favorite. SH3 has a lot going for it with the most refined gameplay and graphics of the series, but it's also the most obviously compromised of the first three games. The game has essentially no exploration outside of the dungeons and a handful of "grab thing, walk a room over, use thing" moments. It's a great game on its own merits, but how it compares to prior entries and their strengths gives a lot of differing thoughts. I would say that, as simply a "video game", that SH3 is the best, as to be expected being the newest, but it's clear pure gameplay is not why people love horror games.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9494556
Emulation is fine, but make sure you can see the post processing effects otherwise you'll lose out on the panic "meter" (it's the whole screen), lighting, and reflections. Software mode works 100%, but I think one of the hardware modes works now if your computer can handle it. Use this timestamp in this video as a reference for what I'm describing.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ektkbejc-sE#t=11m37s

Notice how the screen turns more black&white, and slightly blurry when her heart beats, as Fiona inspects the blood? That's her panicking. The effect gets more pronounced the more she panics, until she loses it. It's important to the gameplay so you understand when you need to calm down.

Just beat both SH2 and SH3 for the first time ever this week. Really loved and enjoyed both, and upset that I didn't play either much sooner. If I can add my two cents, SH 2 had the best story of the 3 games in my opinion, but only because the personal and "simple" nature of it all really suited the gameplay of Silent Hill. As in, minimal cutscenes and exposition dumps and long stretches of just pure gameplay.

However, Heather is my one of my favorite protagonists ever and I still really enjoyed SH3. >>9482770
>>9482789
>>9482861
If I could add, I'd say the biggest issue SH3 had was the pacing. Everything from the beginning in the mall through to when you reach Heather's apartment felt like one extremely drawn out introductory section. I realize the mall alone is supposed to be that, but you go straight from the mall to the subway, then straight to the sewers, then straight to the construction yard, and then the office building, all with no interruption, story elements or anything to essentially let the player "catch their breath". You get one minor moment with Vincent in the office, and then that's it until the apartments. And by that point? You basically hit the halfway mark of the game, you get the big reveal immediately, and then everything kicks into overdrive as you finally get to Silent Hill itself. SH3 really could have used more time to pace out its story and have moments where players could "rest", especially in the first half.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I made a thread the other day about Metroid 1 and some people were saying Metroid 2 was a big improvement. I'm playing it now and I have to say that I completely disagree.
The controls are super sluggish, especially whenever you're in the air. In the first game you slowed down when jumping, but it still felt pretty satisfying; in Metroid 2 it's way too slow. Specifically, there's a big problem with how long you can hold the A button to jump. In Metroid 1, whenever you release the button, you immediately stop rising and begin falling. In Metroid 2, however, after a certain point, it becomes impossible to cancel out your jump, so even if you let go of the button, Samus will continue to rise, and this feels really shitty. If you've played the game you'll know what I mean.
The screen is way too zoomed in and it's retarded that there's no automap. In Metroid 1 they advised you to make your own map, and that's what I did, but such a recommendation is not repeated in Metroid 2's manual, and making your own map would fucking suck because of how zoomed in the screen is. So I've spent ages going over the same little bit of area with the shitty sluggish controls and ear rape music (trying to be suspenseful and atmospheric on the Gameboy was an ambitious concept but it falls flat on its face, it's just a bunch of irritating beeping) and can't find the gay fucking Metroid. I've got 18 left so I'm not even halfway through this bitch.
So the first game was definitely better. I don't know why they put a "mainline" sequel to the original on the Gameboy of all things.

>>9504004
Metroid 2 is split into very easily navigatable chunks of cave that you tackle one by one without ever having a reason to backtrack to anything earlier. This is specifically so you can easily keep the layout in your head and thus be able to play on the go without taking notes or drawing maps, which is why the manual doesn't recommend it.
If you can't find more Metroids despite not having activated a quake after your most recent kill, you always know it's somewhere within a few screens of you, so all you need to do is comb those screens over again to find whatever door you missed.

Just a couple key things, you'll needs a 25 pin to scart adapter cable for the 25 pin port on the back of the set to use scart cables for the consoles you'll want to play on it. Scart is like hdmi for standard definition tv, don't cheap out on the scart cables themselves, never get the cheap chinese crap you can find online. There are a couple great webstores that make tailored made scart cables for every retro console you can think of. If you got lucky on the price for the PVM, you can spare to splurge on good scart cables. The last thing is that this PVM doesn't have built in speakers, so you'll have to find external speakers to connect to it.

That's the minimum, good luck and have fun!

Pic related: my PVM 2530 in my last home before my move

This is a bit misleading. The Dreamcast's real discs were a custom format with more capacity than a CD, so many (most?) games are too big to fit on a CD, and to burn them you have to use shitty scene releases that compress or remove content. You can get around this by using an ODE (optical drive emulator), but it's more expensive and complicated than just burning discs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_of_Duke_Nukem_Forever

>The video game Duke Nukem Forever spent more than 14 years in development, from 1996 to 2011. It is a first-person shooter for Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360,[1] developed by 3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is the sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series. Intended to be groundbreaking, it became an infamous example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; it had been in development under 3D Realms since 1996. Director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, announced the development in 1997, and promotional information for the game was released from 1997 until its release in 2011.

>>9485398
Your post is even more misleading. Most games can be shrunk to fit on a "standard" capacity CD without removing anything but unused space. Most of what can't will fit on a larger capacity CD, which are easily obtainable by any adult with an IQ>70. There are not so shitty scene releases that compress content using more efficnet systems than the original and have negligible loss in quality. Some discs contain content that's not part of the game, not used by the game, and can be removed/moved to another disc without affecting the game in any way. In reality there are only a handfull of games where this is a real problem.
Using an ODE should be less complicated than burning discs, and not much more expensive if at all. Anyone who didn't buy GDEMUs for all their DCs when they were <$40 is a zoomer bandwagoner and thus irrelevent.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9484987
The Dreamcast has a lot of really solid games, but honestly the majority of them have been ported to the PC or other consoles. Unless you like shooters or fighting games, I'd recommend thinking about getting a Saturn instead. It has far more exclusives.

I had one in highschool, me and a bunch of friends all grabbed one when TRU was blowing them out for $50 on clearance. I remember playing NBA 2K1 and making a custom team filled with me and all of my friends, and we'd play games in four player mode. All of the created players based on us had all of their stats set up to maximize dunking, so we'd just do dunks after dunks on the AI teams, it was hilarious.

We'd also do shit like make custom parks for THPS2, and then bring our VMUs to school and trade parks with each other via the VMU to VMU file transfer. Shit really felt like the future back then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tried to convince myself that the Dreamcast was worth it.

Here's what I learned:

- GDEMU isn't worth it, most rips are ok, the only game that I played that had an issue was Bust a Move (WinCE) (can't play bgm), but it's a simple 2d game so I just emulate it instead. ask yourself, do I really need to pay +$100 usd to switch between 10 games? or just buy 10-15 cheap cds instead.
- Shenmue is worth it because it looks different than the remaster on PC, and the new redub mod was recently released. But the game has some slowdowns. Check the overclock mod if you care about more performance.
- The fan is NOISY, if you care about noise check the noctua fan mod.
- Lightgun games, if you have CRT TV go for it, LCD lightgun mods are expensive.
- Fighting games, worth playing, look and sound great, go for it unless you want to use an arcade stick.
- Resident Evil, Skies of Arcadia, Jet Set Radio, worth it.
- Soul Reaver has better models and effects that the PC version, worth it.
- Tony Hawk 2 runs at 30fps. Xbox has better textures and it's a different game (2X), better version, but dreamcast has the "proper classic" version.
- Rayman 2 worth it because it's closer to the "classic" version.
- The 480p picture quality makes this console a MUST. It's amazing to play 90s games in this resolution.
- DCHDMI isn't worth it. I got a $25 usd VGA box from AliExpress that also outputs HDMI and the picture quality is amazing, I have an OLED B7 that actually does a great job upscaling the 480p output.
- The controller is a hit and miss, the camera control in Soul Reaver with the D-pad is just horrendous with that layout.

So: small library, but amazing picture quality, and iconic games, IMO expensive mods like DCHDMI and GDEMU are a waste of money, check the library, you will have a great time with this console, but probably just with a dozen of games lol, currently playing Skies of Arcadia and Soul Reaver.

posts.com: Dreamcast is a real fun time if you don't have to buy the games. don't burn discs, as mentioned by others it won't work all the time, and it'll tire out the already highly persnickety DC laser. I've owned four Dreamcasts in my life and the laser went out on the first three. last one I put gdemu on to sidestep the issue entirely and we're golden. just remember that gdemu is a bit of a bitch, if it stops working try to wiggle it about to reseat it, I thought my DC was broken for the entire last year before I tried that. also there's some voltage wonkiness, something about expecting 12v and getting 14 or 15 and it can make your shit too hot. there's some tweaks to fix that online, I just found out about it earlier today though and haven't delved in enough to speak intelligently about the matter.

>>9499630
Recently played through LoI for the first time

+
Great music.
Great atmosphere and art direction. Did a great job of bringing the SOTN vibe to the 3D.

+/-
Cheesy story/VA. I actually found it entertaining and charming, but objectively speaking this is probably a flaw.

-
Boring combat. You can pretty much just mash square and triangle mindlessly to kill 90% of the enemies.
Mediocre level design. Most of the game is just empty hallways or a big room where the doors shut and you're forced to fight the aforementioned mindless goons.
Godawful platforming. Despite there only being a handful of platforming sections, there were still too many. No idea how this got past the playtesting stage.

Overall the game kinda felt like the 1st DMC, but without the fun combat. Worth a playthrough for Igavania diehards, but not much else. I plan on playing CoD too eventually as well.

>>9499186
As zoomies say, sounds like a skill issue.
But really, yes it sucks if you die on MB and have to restock. But it makes the first attempt that much more toe-curling and intense. The first time I fought MB was exciting, and so was the tenth, because of that decision alone. It punishes failure heavily, but it never ends the game for you. A determined player can easily kill MB without taking a hit, if they choose to keep trying the fight rather than stock up on health. It's really a big defenseless creature, once you figure out how to freeze the spaghetti-o beams. And there are good spots to replenish your supplies nearby, as well as an E-tank very conspicuously placed near the entrance to the fight. I think that particular detail alone proves it was a conscious, deliberate decision, and I consider it to be effective and fun.
Of course, I first bought the game when I was like fifteen, and I've always enjoyed a stiff but fair challenge in my games, so I can understand a 7 year old being really, really frustrated with it if they're used to more beginner-friendly fare. But a plunge into the depths of a hellish, alien environment where every living thing is hostile and a biomechanical supercomputer is observing your every move should absolutely not be beginner friendly, no matter what modern games would have you believe with their onscreen tutorials that stay there until the credits roll. It's beyond a cliché at this point, but they do not makes games like this one anymore. Some will be pleased about that fact. I am not. But I'm happy I still get to play this game.

>tiring and frustrating without a map, boring if you make your own map, and pointless if you look up a map.
I haven't played Metroid yet, but this is very relatable criticism. I felt this way playing FF1 and FF2. The dungeons are so straight-forward that making a map is tedious, and you skip all of the dead-ends and pointlessness if you use a pre-made map (and the difficulty is based on random encounters in the dungeons, so beelining makes them much easier). Yet, the random encounter rate is so high that it's easy to zone out and forget where you are on a particular floor here and there, and if you don't make a map and happen to retread a lot of ground, you end up burning a lot of your actual time because of the number of unnecessary fights you have to go through. I felt punished no matter what, as it came to this particular facet of the game design.

La Mulana trolling in game design form. A good puzzle is intuitive, it introduces the variables and gives you an idea of how far you are supposed to shoot. Zelda 1 gives you tips so you can narrow down how to solve some of its (better) puzzles. Metroid's puzzles usually involve some kind of wall you forgot to hump, so it's less about solving a puzzle and more about being through with each room.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9503897
first, go to wii.guide, and follow the instructions
get a USB hard drive, 1TB is good, doesn't matter how slow it is, format it FAT32
the homebrew apps you need:
>USB Loader GX (loads Wii and Gamecube games, also provides emulated NAND support)
>Nintendont (provides virtual machine for Gamecube games)
>Wii Mod Lite (loads the WiiWare that doesn't work in emuNAND into real NAND)
>Genesis Plus GX - emulates Master System, Genesis, Sega CD
>FCE Ultra RX - emulates NES
>Snes9x RX - emulates SNES
>Wii-Mednafen - emulates TG16
For N64 you're going to want to stick to Virtual Console releases. There is a PS1 emulator, but it's pretty limited and I don't recommend it unless you're desperate.
GBAtemp is the main place to go for help with the Wii; all the homebrew developers are on that site.
Finally, I recommend getting a Classic Controller Pro.

Dragon Quest 4 for PS1. If you go by remakes the first five games still follow a logical technological progression.
>1 and 2 on SNES look like basic early SNES games
>3 is a gorgeous late SNES game
>4 is on PS1 and mixes 2D and 3D, arranged MIDI soundtrack
>5 is full 3D on PS2 with orchestral music
Currently the main options to play DQ4 in America are the NES version (NES RPGs never feel good, don't even bother with the reply) or the DS version (made for two handheld screens instead of one screen, gimped audio quality compared to PS1).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9503253
Because it was a home arcade system. The controller was designed around playing arcade games, many of the early games were arcade ports, the whole console was designed around being a home version of one of Sega's arcade systems and as such the marketing always focused on the ability to bring the arcades to your home.

Sega later tried to get some RPGs on the system but by that point it was too late.

>>9503253
I think others have said this already but to elaborate
1. Outsold hard by PCE and SFC—see >>9495753 . Mega Drive had just 3.6 mln units sold in Japan (4.4 if you count Mega CD too). Meanwhile, SFC had about 16 mln by 1995, and PCE had ~8 mln (of which 6 were PCE and 1.9 mln of Turbo Duo, also add 0.9 mln of CD-ROM2).
Basically, that means that MD was at most just 15% of the market, and SFC was like 60%, rest was PCE. So it was like the situation with Saturn vs PSX and N64 in the West. Few big companies wanted to make original games for it, because there was no reason to.
Small install base, tiny game sales in the order of ~200k for big hits (see >>9495731 ). All this meant it was unfeasible to make an RPG for MD alone, unless we're talking ports.
2. The console was just the worst fit for RPGs out of the 3. SFC was the obvious most popular choice (biggest brand, Square & Enix, fitting hardware). PCE came out earlier, already had a more popular CD add-on, meaning that it would attract most of the RPG devs that weren't satisfied with Nintendo for some reason, and/or wanted the benefits of the CD.
MD was made for fast-paced arcades. It had no real advantage over competition when it came to RPGs. Also, no one mentioned this yet, but there's this weird thing that few games on MD had saves to begin with.
Maybe that's why most 3rd party devs like Treasure were making fast arcade action games for the platform.
^With all that said, RPGs still dominated the sales of MD games (see >>9495731
and >>9495735 ), which is kind of ironic. Goes to show that RPGs were a huge deal in Japan in 4th-5th gen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495706
Adding more objectives on higher difficulties is the only good option the designers had. It's boring to just add more guards on a higher difficulty (which it does, but it's secondary to the new objectives) or the even worse option of changing their behavior. You're playing a stealth game, so the inability to kill guards is important to make sure you stay undetected and be more careful instead of: "Oh well, I was careless and got caught, time for a sword fight!" Having to get in a sword fight (or run away on difficulties that prevent killing) works, because Thief (or more accurately Thief 1) is meant to evoke tension and fear of getting caught and to stray you away from confrontation. The blackjack (note: there is no specific spot you have to hit guards with it, you can do it from any direction, even the front, provided they aren't in combat) works as a mechanic, because the choice to use it or not use it changes the way the game it played, if you knock guards out you get the burden of hiding their bodies, so other AI don't see them. And if you choose to not use the blackjack, then the only suitable playstyle is ghosting (not alerting anyone to the point where they start to search for you) which makes the game even more difficult to those who desire while also changing the way you play.
The beauty of Thief comes down to letting the player form a playstyle without having them pick a class or such, but from the game's mechanics, Thief gives you so much freedom of approach while only making restrictions when necessary.

>>9498840
>This game would have been too difficult for westerners.

That was a bullshit excuse. "Westerners" back then were better at video games than easterners, the audiance actually seeked a challenge. In the west, most magazines had a challenge rating, for instance Nintendo Power had "lasting challenge", that or the "lastability" grade was heavily based on the game's difficulty and not just how many levels there were, in other words the harder the game was, the better the grade. Tons of action games were made harder for the west and it wasn't just because of "rentals", and the inverse is also true, western action games like Battletoads were made easier for the Japanese market.

Meanwhile in Japan, no such "challenge" rating in magazines and the audiance complained that even mainstream jRPGs were too hard (Final Fantasy 2, 3, Mother, Dragon Quest 2, etc).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9504378
Holy fuck you are dim at getting the point despite mentioned multiple times here.

The UNNAMED PROJECT that was being worked on was a SEQUEL, not to MARIO the fat guido, but to SUPER MARIO BROS THE GAME. As in literally, "we made/perfected the running left to right platform game, can we do something now that takes the same concept as SMB, but instead make levels with a vertical focus instead of horizontal?"

THAT is what DokiDoki and Mario USA are based on. NEITHER of them were designed from the ground up, both of them were literally slapped onto a project they were dicking around with. First Doki because they got the contract to do a game using those mascots, then Mario for the western release and future releases.

If they didn't get the deal to make Doki, it could have gone either way if it was released at all. Releasing it as a budget disk title with minimal risk since they were contracted to release ANY game using those characters gave them an easy way to test this vertical focused platformer they had been dicking with. The arabian themes are leftover from that version, probably, but thats still literally a skin applied to something that they were working on that had no identity attached to it yet. Without Doki, it either would have been a scrapped project, gotten a new IP attached to it or they eventually would have decided to just use Mario anyway seeing as it was being designed as a successor to Super Mario THE GAME. Doki was not 100% designed from the ground up just for that ip to have a game, it was a skin given to concepts already in the development phase.

So yes, BOTH Mario 2 games are sequels to Super Mario Bros. 2 Japan is a literal continuation of the same first game while USA/Doki/US 2 is a sequel to trying new things with the ideas and gameplay of Super Mario they had already done.

>>9497390
If you can beat the alien spaceship without dying, you have something like 60 grenades and a full flame shot for the final boss (just jump over the Drop Shot right at the end when you get the walker with the double jump), and you can dodge his attacks by jumping in and out of the Metal Slug. The flame shot alone can take out half his HP (he is at the mid point when your ally in the saucer shows up). the grenades you can throw in from point blank but then you risk getting hit by his attacks.
It's a case of "be quick or be dead". You should be having huge damage potential there, you just have to be good enough to unload it.

also occasionally when dodging, it spawns a machinegun which you can run into by accident, which lowers your DPS a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9499552
The only ones I find a chore are a small portion of Tall, Tall Mountain, and mostly the tiny side of Tiny, Huge Island.

TTM is too linear with ascending the mountain, and the camera angle is a little annoying for stuff like the red coins.

THM is just a nuisance to navigate as it can be too easy to slip up and fall off the island, because it's just too tiny.
Part of the problem is that the game's controls were fine tuned to the original N64 analogue stick which has a huge pivot. Modern controls have a much smaller pivot so finer movements on N64 games are unreliable. Think stuff like Bow and Arrow aiming in Ocarina of Time / Majora's Mask, it's an issue that persists in official releases like Wii Virtual Console.

MOST games you'd want to play run perfectly, especially if you install a config file. PS3's are cheaper than a PS2+HDD Module at the moment, so check a compatibility list for the PS2 Classics emulator and see what you wanna play before you write off the PS3.
>>9503783
On a typical CRT the PS3 will output the remastered games at 480i which will usually be a higher resolution than the PS2 (games typically ran at 448i).

I've got NTSC San Andreas running on both a PS2 and PS3, but I think my PS3 might be outputting PAL60 or something since something is different enough about the signal that the TV automatically scaled my settings to adjust (even my service menu seems to be running at a different resolution).

Nevertheless, many PS2 games like SA were letterboxed and squished at 448i or lower, so I've stretched the picture on my TV settings (minimap would otherwise be an oval). Since the minimap is a circle on both, we can say that the PS3 doesn't stretch the picture to 480i and will output interlaced games at their original resolution.

Some PS2 games however run at 240p, which the PS3 will upscale to 480i since it cannot do 240p. Examples of 240p titles include Ico and Shadow of the Colossus. If you like how those games look on PS2, play the PS2 versions on a PS2 instead of the remasters. For the same reason, PS1 games (the majority of which are 240p) will be upscaled too.

posts.com:
>>9494075
You're in luck anon, here's the definitive classic-style Castlevania guide.
>Castlevania 1 (NES)
Great game, and if you could beat this one you can handle most of the ones after.
>Castlevania 2: Simon's Quest (NES)
Don't bother, it's rather boring. The progression is generally pretty obtuse and you'd think the dungeon levels would be the fun action levels but nope, they just suck and don't even have cool unique aesthetics.
>Castlevania 3: Dracula's Curse (NES)
The best 8-bit Castlevania, with multiple routes and playable characters. Play the Japanese version for a richer soundtrack, slightly better graphical effects, and a more tough-but-fair challenge as originally intended.
>Super Castlevania 4 (SNES)
Surprisingly underrated these days, my personal favorite Classicvania. The graphics and sound are awesome and the gameplay is fun as hell, with more streamlined controls. It is easier than usual for Castlevania which makes it more approachable to just sit back and play, but if you love the hardcore challenge of previous Castlevania games you may be disappointed.
>Castlevania: Rondo of Blood (TG-CD)
The fan favorite Classicvania. Whereas SC4 went full on with the Halloween horror aesthetic, this one goes full early-90s anime and it's a really fun vibe. It's on a CD so it's got voice acted cutscenes and CD quality music. The controls are more stiff than SC4, and the challenge is cranked back up, but it still feels a little more fair than the NES games. Alternate routes are back and you can unlock a second character.
>Castlevania Chronicles (X68000, PS1)
Okay reimagining of the first game. The difficulty here is retardedly high, and it's just the worst 16-bit Castlevania by far. The PS1 version adds an """easy""" mode but the music for that mode is really goofy remixes.
>Castlevania Bloodlines (Genesis)
This one's pretty fun, and it's on Genesis so it feels a little more "hardcore". Not as classic as 4 or Rondo but worth playing.

>both the official translation, the translation on that wiki AND the "super accurate retranslation you need to use because you'll get stuck otherwise" fuck up the ONLY goddamn thing the official translation actually mistranslated in a way that actively hurts your chances of beating the game
Holy shit.

(ブンケン does not mean "clue", it means "book". The people telling you "clues to Dracula's riddle are in (location)" are actually supposed to be telling you there's one or more hidden books in that location that you should be looking for. Not understanding that means you probably won't find the book that tells you how to use the blue crystal, which means you'll get stuck because that's not a solution you'll magically stumble over)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9502440
vanilla > limit removing (crispy) > boom > MBF21 > Zdoom > GZdoom
each is backwards compatible with the ones before it, and at every level you can have dehacked scripts, which is why knee deep in knee deep in zdoom has so many gameplay changes while being "vanilla"
SOME dehacked is incompatible with GZDoom but those exceptions are usually well documented and the wad author will have a disclaimer saying it does not work in GZDoom

Gonna copy and paste /vm/'s guide and replace relevant bits:
So, if you want to yell at your fellow racers and call them some slurs, here's what you need to do:
1. Install the Mumble client - https://dl.mumble.info/latest/stable/client-windows-x64
2. Enable the "Link" plugin by doing the following:
Configure -> Settings
Plugins -> Tick "Link to Game and Transmit position" -> Tick "Enable" for the "Link" plugin in the plugins list -> Click Apply
3. Connect to the /srb2k/ mumble server:
>Address: 51.161.34.159
>Port: (leave as default)
>Username: (whatever you want i guess)
4. You should be put into a room with other racers. At this point, you're good to boot up the game and join the server.

If everything is set up correctly, the proximity chat should be instant once you get into a game.

In case you forgot, the server IP is 51.161.34.159

>>9501758
Soul = had some degree of effort put into it (especially if the hardware was extremely limited), gives you a warm feeling inside, was made to fit someone's vision/fantasy rather than to sate the desires of the widest audience possible.

I think the last point might be a big factor in what makes people call out a lot of new stuff as "soulless". Most people weren't connected back then so a lot of art felt especially idiosyncratic. But now that most of us are connected to the internet and are bumping elbows with everyone and drinking from the same watering hole its hard for things to feel unique anymore without feeling either like we've seen it before or that it's meant to appeal to the masses (the backrooms)

And like everybody else has said, 2 was the best and then you could ignore them until Black came out

- Great second look.

>>9503079
>Killer7 has PC port which is better I believe?
To be honest, it's kinda a mixed bag concerning whether to get the PC version or emulate on Dolphin. PC has uncapped framerate, lower loading time, and (if you want to play on kb/m) better mouse controls. Dolphin has proper anti-aliasing, properly supports windowed mode, and runs on older hardware. The loading time is kinda a non-issue since the GCN version of Killer7 was pretty fast, though it is noticeable sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9500337
It's really hard to say. The story of the Dreamcast is more than just the success or failure of the hardware in relation to competing models. Somehow, there existed a brief period where multiple different teams of creative, passionate individuals came together on this platform to produce a little slice in history of vivid, unique, entertaining, sometimes downright experimental games. It was a rare brief peak of free creative spirit and it's hard to really pin down what cultivates these, other than living in a vibrant, enjoyable time where individualism that nourishes such minds and talents flourishes. The Dreamcast's golden age lasted from roughly 1999 to 2001. What happened in late 2001? I don't want to pin it down to just one certain event, but there's too many variables to consider whether such a soulful time in gaming could last much longer than these fleeting, shining moments.

>>9490142
anon, even the best-optimized 3D games on it had low framerates and low res. and most of them were crappy racers with tiny drawing distance.
i think there's a whole breed of retards who think GBA being 32 bit meant it had same specs as PSX, and that Nintendo just "didn't work hard enough on 3d". except unlike PSX, GBA had no real GPU or 3D hardware. if you understand what this means, you know you will need the CPU to render everything, and it will be done at a very slow speed.
pair this with the need for batteries, tiny res, lack of analog, etc., and you will understand why it didn't have much 3D.
and yes, surely, 20 years later some dedicated autists managed to put Tomb Raider on GBA, but no one would have time and money to bother with this back in the day when the system's life cycle was only 3 years.
instead, you got smooth good 2D and actually good 2D games. virtually of the 3D GBA titles I've played were shovelware racers, gimmicky trash and yuroshit. so I'm glad that GBA devs went with 2D instead of chasing 3D.

>Why do people call it a "life cycle"? Shelf life perhaps, but the GBA doesn't cycle by any stretch of the imagination.

There were games being released for the GBA up to 2008. I would say Nintendo supported it well enough. The GBA was doing great sales wise, but Sony decided to enter into the hand held market with their PSP, that supported sub level PS2 style graphics and has a disc drive. The PSP looked futuristic compared to the GBA. Which caused Nintendo to literally throw the DS into development, because they were scared of losing the handheld market, like they were the home console market. Nintendo smartly put more focus on the DS as a 3D machine, as it is better specced than the GBA. The DS has the GBA hardware in it, and it is used to control the second screen. Nintendo was able to get away with selling the GBA alongside the DS, through backwards compatibility.

Long story short, I dropped my retrobit saturn usb controller on a hard stone floor from considerable height, and now the left shoulder button is fucked (internal switch got bend to fuck)
I really liked it and used it for both genesis and saturn emulation.

Was thinking if just buying a replacement but I see they also have licenced sega genesis 6 button controllers *with* added shoulder buttons.

How is the genesis ergonomics wise?
Saturn layout seems more comfy but i never held the genesis 6 btn to compare with.
Advantage of the genesis is the additional mode button not present on the saturn.

Also I prefer wired, and dont mind about buying another controller.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9502331
I have both, I use the Genesis one for Genesis games and the Saturn one for Saturn games. Or alternatively if you're on a budget you could also try the M30 which is kind of middle of the road in terms of design but smaller than both.

If you want specifics though, the Genesis is slightly wider and lacks the raised shoulders for L and R if you like the way those feel on your index fingers. My Genesis controller is also quieter than the Saturn one, maybe because it doesn't have the microswitches or whatever. It's up to you though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9502339
(cont.) Alright so you actually have a few more options. If you're on Linux or PC you can grab a Genesis Mini 3-button controller for cheap. For Android or Chrome you can either wait for a good price on the Switch Genesis controller (highly recommend if you prefer this style), or wait for the Big 6, which was supposed to be released in October but got quietly delayed until who knows when. Personally I prefer the look and feel of the three button, makes me feel like I'm controlling a space ship or something which ironically is perfect for shmups and rail shooters, but also games like Sonic and Streets of Rage.

The Big 6 is really the best of both worlds, but again it's been delayed, so we'll probably have to wait until the end of this year or early next year. Shame as I was planning on getting it for myself for Christmas, but the Switch Genesis controller is good enough for me, for now.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9500768

That training event sequence is pretty silly. I think maybe they intended for you to go in and try once, fail horribly, turn to other quests for a while (gaining a level or two in the process), come back again thinking your stronger character might win this time, fail somewhat less horribly, go out to grind some more, etc. etc. until at some point you came close enough to actually winning that you'd finally want to retry immediately. It could seem relatively natural if done that way.

A problem with that, though, is that the first version of the fight that actually feels winnable is so stupidly easy that it doesn't even seem as if Stom is trying. They should have made the slope of decreasing difficulty much more gradual at that point, so that you could feel like you were really accomplishing something. Or better yet, the fight could have been a normal battle right from the start, with your normal movement and combat controls, rather than a mindless test of your button-mashing speed. Oh well, it's still a cute sequence.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9502590
Untrue. Japanese 8 came out on PlayStation first in late 1996, English 8 came out on PlayStation around the same time as Japanese 8 on Saturn in early 1997, then finally English 8 came out on Saturn. The confusion comes from a poorly worded segment on G4 that didn't specify it was it was talking about Sony America. Note that the extra anthology booklet only came out in North America. On top of that, the segment never even claimed that the Saturn version was the original vision like it was cited. It was all-around misunderstood.
The leaked early protos are of the PlayStation version for MM8 & Saturn version version for MMX4, supporting this further.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played the PS1 game when I was like... 7 years old, and I really liked building my robot. That stuff was really compelling. The customisation is the real meat on the bones of this game, which is fortunate because the gameplay itself was pretty weak. But in fairness, I can't criticise it too harshly for that, it's only like when you play a mediocre RPG because you still get that nice dopamine hit from getting sweet loot.

To me, a real mech game should have a cockpit view and obtuse controls that make you really feel like you're a PILOT, not just that you're playing as a sentient robot. If they can pull off something that feels a bit more realistic and less weeby, I might be more interested.

But yeah, I think there are a lot of hipsters who claim the game is better than it is because it's FromSoft, much like with King's Field. I find it funny because they act like FromSoft have always had this enlightened genius game design when in reality, like most successes, Dark Souls was just kind of a lucky experimental combination of the right ingredients.

OP is a shit troll but in all honesty it does kind of surprise me Fromsoftware was able to not only survive as long as they did with pretty much AC being their flagship franchise but they also survived a long time where as most or perhaps all companies that were in their tier died, then From goes on to be without a doubt one of the top tier companies in gaming for many years on after Dark Souls. And especially now with ER the mass of normies most certainly have to see From as one of gamings top premiere companies out there.

Its really a wild and very deserved story of success imo. Going from being the King's Field and AC devs to then hitting there stride with the Souls formula and getting themselves out of that perception of being a lower tier company. I guess filling in that mecha niche helped them to be carried as you put it. Just think of all those other companies that were in their shoes at one point. Most didn't make it to today. They either got bought out and completely gutted until they were a soulless in name only company or they just were outright made defunct. Lets take EA for example, you got Bioware which was actually honestly at the time of EA's acqusition a much bigger and more known company than From. People loved Bioware even prior to EA. Then you also had Lionhead which practically nobody even remembers today as its just a defunct company. From though? They somehow outlasted so many of their peers despite not being top tier for most of their history.

I hated my time with Armored Core (Nexus)... until
It was a lot of just doing missions, failing them because my mech sucks and restarting the PS2 (I forget why, but I think there's a price you pay for failing missions) and just ended up grinding out the whole game like that.
Slowly but surely, I got better at it, and I went up the ranks, and got better at it, but it never felt good (until). It's a game that still felt comfortable because it's sort of like a Gran Turismo career mode where you're going through a long career mode over several months I guess of playing the game and after that much time, finishing the game feels really meat-y and rewarding.
But the game part was still pretty trash
Until. I got a giant laser cannon, which you get at the end of the game. It's a fucking giant laser which I don't know the name of off the top of my head, but you go into turret mode when you activate it, and become unable to move, and then the fucking thing just charges for like a minute, and then fires off and completely wrecks everything. The moment I got that laser was when the game became fun, I was just wrecking everything. But I'd say almost every part of that game was very tedious

>>9486870
>a real mech game should have obtuse controls that feels a bit more realistic
Realistically if controlling a mech was obtuse, it would not be used as an combat vehicle. You don't have the luxury of carefully designing which direction your legs are going to move independently of your torso when you're being shot at. Machines with legs have to move with the same intuition that a living creature would, or else you're better off using tanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I have a very weird contribution to this thread. Earlier this year I watched the Austin Powers movies for the first time and fell in love with them. I then went and looked to see if my hobby ever had crossed paths with these films I love and sure enough they had! 3 times in fact! I then promptly scooped em all up so I'm one of the few autistic retards who can say have a complete Austin Powers video game collection. One of which is Austin Powers Pinball for the Playstation. It's a pretty strange release, featuring only 2 tables based around International Man of Mystery and Spy Who Shagged Me despite releasing a little bit after Goldmember hit theaters. The physics are fine I suppose, standard pinball fare, but the game just seems really hastily slapped together. Another strange thing missing from the game is a digitized version of the real Austin Powers pinball table. It's such a strange release but I love its weirdness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493759
Lots of reasons. It's been known since forever ago that Woolsey didn't deliver the most faithful translation, not to mention all the censorship, which is why we got that old Sky Render fan translation over twenty years ago (that we now know to be amateurish as fuck). Then the GBA game came out, and its translation was recognized to be much more accurate, but it had two problems: first, by that point, Woolsey's script had obtained meme status, and while the GBA script kept some of his lines, it changed or tossed enough of them out to piss a vocal part of the fanbase off. Second, the GBA version had problems of its own, namely shit music, slowdown and lower resolution, among others. So now you have a bunch of Woolsey fanboys who like the idea of a more accurate script while still staying true to the Woolsey "flavor", all on the mostly superior SNES version, and before long, we got the Ted Woolsey Uncensored hack. Problem is, its creator didn't know a lick of moon, so all he did was mix and match bits and pieces of the Woolsey, GBA and Sky Render scripts as he pleased, and to top it off, he decided to also make it an overarching "game improvement" hack that fixed a gorillion longstanding bugs and added QoL changes. This effectively set the mold for all like-minded hacks that followed, all of which were made by people with no nip-speaking credentials, and all of which were convinced they could do it better than the last, especially given they're not constrained to just script changes, but outright game changes as well, so every new release is just feature creep. It's telling that it wasn't until like last year that we got a simple, no frills port of the GBA script to the SNES version.

tl;dr autism and one-upmanship

I remember when the NES version came out, with that coupon for the free pizza that came with it. It was one of the biggest events in our childhood life. That pizza was so good.

My single earliest arcade memory is probably playing Double Dragon. Discovering it with my best friend and there's two characters so, naturally, that's who we pretended to be in our random outdoor childhood romps for the next year. And of course they weren't Billy and Jimmy Lee at the time, the side of the machine said "Spike" and "Hammer". I remember getting to the forest stage, felt surreal, watching this strange digital world unfold in gleaming phosphorous lights. Could never get past the twin Abobos back then. I think they were green?

posts.name: Anonymous
